results.name: Triangle of coefficients of a version of the Hermite polynomials defined by P(x, n) = x*P(x, n - 1) - n*P(x, n - 2).
comment: Hochstadt defines the standard Hermite polynomials of A066325 via H(x,n+1)=x*H(x,n)-n*H(x,n-1); note the index shift relative to the definition in the current sequence.

As a consequence, the polynomials defined here are orthogonal with weight exp(-x^2/2) in a restricted sense than the usual Hermite Polynomials, i.e. the integral of P(x,n)*P(x,m)*exp(-x^2/2) over x=-infinity..infinity vanishes for m=n-1 (mod 2), as for any system of polynomials with separated even and odd functions, but not for the general case of m<>n as with the Hermite polynomials H(x,n) or other classical polynomials. (End)
reference: Harry Hochstadt, The Functions of Mathematical Physics, Dover, New York, 198, pp. 8, 42-43.
link: R. Paris, A uniform asymptotic expansion for the incomplete gamma function, Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics, 148 (2002), p. 223-239 (See p. 333 and A066325/A099174. From Tom Copeland, Jan 03 2016)
mathematica: P[x, 0] = 1; P[x, 1] = x; P[x_, n_] := P[x, n] = x*P[x, n - 1] - n*P[x, n - 2]; Table[ExpandAll[P[x, n]], {n, 0, 10}]; a = Table[CoefficientList[P[x, n], x], {n, 0, 10}]; Flatten[a]
program: (PARI) polx(n) = if (n == 0, 1, if (n == 1, x, x*polx(n - 1) - n*polx(n - 2)));
tabl(nn) = {for (n = 0, nn, pol = polx (n); for (i = 0, n, print1(polcoeff(pol, i), ", ");); print(););} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Feb 12 2014
def P(x, n): return 1 if n==0 else x if n==1 else x*P(x, n - 1) - n*P(x, n - 2)
def a(n): return Poly(P(x, n), x).all_coeffs()[::-1]
for n in range(11): print(a(n)) # _Indranil Ghosh_, May 26 2017
